instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SDA: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SDA? SMBUS_CHGR_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SCL: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SCL? SMBUS_CHGR_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message:
Had no green light on this board.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was 0 volt.
Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and now I have green light but only 12,27 Volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

Can it only be dead SMC or is it something that I'm missing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message: Check if <SIGNAL>SMC_REST_L</SIGNAL> is present....  Also check data lines <SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL> are not low ....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_REST_L</SIGNAL> is 0 Volt
The other two isn't low

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message:
just noticed that the area around the smc looks a bit bad.
I'll try a reflow

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message: after some heat on the smc <SIGNAL>SMC_REST_L</SIGNAL> is 3,4 volt but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still 12,27 volt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message: That sounds like a bad SMC

threads.message: I know. One day I might learn to replace smc

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message: i re flowed my first yesterday, to fix a short as a last resort, it took a lot of heat, a lot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message:
Reflow SMC to eliminate a short?
How can a reflow (even reballing) eliminate a short in any chip???
Preheat entire board, this will help you a lot...
No need to do it normally, but it helps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 16346"]Reflow SMC to eliminate a short?
How can a reflow (even reballing) eliminate a short in any chip???
Preheat entire board, this will help you a lot...
No need to do it normally, but it helps.[/QUOTE]

last resort, as is full short, everything else removed, caps first, then chips, then resistors and filters then the last thing was smc

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message:
Impossible to eliminate a short in such way!
You must change it.

The reflow/reballing "solve" intrernal problems related with broken connection (inside chip); doesn't apply for any (internal) short...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message: i dont think you are reading my messages properly, if you dont understand stop replying, the point is that i had already removed everything on the entire line and the smc was the only thing that was left, it was reflowed and then REMOVED and the short persisted, im not asking for help with this, this is not my post, this was about reflowing an smc the reason why is irrelevant

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
threads.message:
I understood you perfectly.
I just wanted to explain you, do not waste time in the future reflowing a chip thinking that way a short will disappear.
Remove it directly, when other things have been already tested; as last resort.
And also gave you a hint to help replacing SMC; which takes a lot of hot, as you told...
If you've been offensed as I tried to help you, no problem, I will no bother you anymore...
